Subject: Question about applicability of NEAT to a particular domain
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=197999825; y=SGqoqgz50VP70ff33OT1vL_lipAgNLz7xBLMLLJxBiRy1uA

--20cf3054a527bf643e049e8eaef6
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1

Just want to pick the group's brain about something:

I'm working on a team that has produced a WebService layer.  This layer is
an abstraction layer between clients (web and IVR) and the back-end billing
systems.  The logs for this product are immense.  They log the inputs and
outputs for every call coming in to the layer, and another log entry for
every call out to the external dependencies.

In this iteration that just completed, I started work on a script to parse
those logs and look for instances where exceptions were raised as responses
to requests.  The intention is to alert the team in the event that there are
ever an unusual amount of activity.  I was thinking that the IDEAL thing
would be if this script were to learn the definition of "normal" and only
alert when something truly abnormal took place.

Here's the thing:  the definition of "normal" changes by the hour, and by
the day.  Mondays are typically the busiest days, and it falls off as the
week progresses.  Holidays can alter that.  The 1st and the 15th also seem
to influence it.  Around the noon hour is a peak time, and after around 5 it
goes back up, and then falls off again in the late evening.  The things that
people call for also change depending on the time of day or the day of
week.  So the definition of "normal" is highly complex.  Too complex,
really, to manually model it.

As a first-stab at it, I just created "floating thresholds" that rise or
fall a little bit whenever the actual is significantly over or under the
current threshold.  This seems to kind of work, but I'm not satisfied with
it.

What I would like to see is an unsupervised learning algorithm.  I break
down the logs into the bits and pieces necessary for it to "learn" the
definition of normal, and then have it tell me how "normal" it thinks it
is.  But it has to learn the definition of "normal" from data that is not
always normal.  I don't want to have to try to come up with training data by
pulling out the "abnormal" data.  I don't want to have to tell it if it is
right or not for every one of the millions of log entries per day over the
several months of data that I would need in order for it to understand what
"normal" is.

Do any of you have any ideas about how Neat might be applied in a problem
domain like this?  Or are there other Machine Learning techniques that would
be more applicable to this problem?

Thanks for any feedback you might have!

-- 
John Arrowwood
http://www.FindingResonance.com/ - blog
http://www.TransformativeTherapiesInc.com/
http://www.irie-inc.com/

--20cf3054a527bf643e049e8eaef6
